comments.commentBody:
Those missiles were not banned by the sanctions, even we admitted that at the time.

Russia held back and then canceled the sale as a courtesy, while relations were better between Russia and the US.

Now we no longer have those good relations with Russia. Than the hawks for that. Courtesy is over.

Not surprising, not in the least. We arm Russia's enemies, and they arm ours. It doesn't all go one way. So blame the hawks, not Obama. He's right.

Lee Harrison, 18 Apr post

Dear Dr. Harrison,

We can agree that the accounting for "offset payments" is problematic.

In fact, it is worse than that. It rises to the level of Papal Indulgences in the Middle Ages.

Monitoring and assigning local origins to a colorless, odorless, tasteless trace gas ubiquitous to nature is a regulatory Gordian Knot guaranteed to create opportunities for large scale corruption.

Organized crime has already moved in on this idea, in Sicily and in Spain.

If climate scientists really oppose biofuel and carbon offset scams, they have been remarkably timid about saying so.

Don't you see that your climate change cause loses credibility when these squirrelly "renewable energy" scams latch onto it like parasites?

Wood pellet power stations, fuel ethanol, palm oil plantations for biodiesel, biodiesel from old french fry oil and all the other biofuel schemes need to labeled for what they are.

They are worthless scams, with their vampire's teeth sunk into the neck of the environmental movement, sucking the blood and energy out of it to enrich a new set of self-righteous special interests.
No, military drones.  We don't need commercial pilots.
Thank you Kevin for your excellent comment.

50 years ago, some of the women who had been my friends in high school then became flight attendants, rather than attend college. Though I envied the glamour and seeming sophistication of their lives, I was surprised when they soon related stories of bacchanals, drunken pilots, sleepless nights and absolute lack of attention to pilot fitness by certain carriers. It was enough that I got in the habit of visiting the cockpit for a few minutes before each flight for quite a few years afterwards. I never noticed anyone unworthy of my trust, but unfortunately, the airlines rarely did either.
Ummm,because unlike buses, jets can carry several hundred passengers.

It may not make a difference to you whether this was declared a suicide or a homicide (murder), but I'm sure the distinction matters to the person who NOW may be too reluctant to seek help for severe depression and suicidal thoughts, because he or she may be worried that they will be labeled as a possible  'mass murderer.'
No, I am not talking about piloting drones for commercial passengers.  I am talking drones for other purposes such as military drone pilots.

The argument in support of feeding and housing feral cats is without merit, irregardless of proximity to a protected bird species.

Here on the outskirts of Boston, we just struggled through one of the most brutal winters in 150 years. As has been widely reported, it was our snowiest winter on record. Perhaps more impressive, the stretch from January to March was colder than any similar stretch going back to 1885. Many nights were defined by temperatures well below zero and punctuated by fierce winds that dropped windchills 20 to 35 below.

Many nights held truly deadly weather conditions. I often wondered how the local animals could possibly survive such extreme challenges. And yet - two weeks ago - I was shocked to see an old face: one of the local feral cats had indeed made it through. Not only did this cat survive on its own through months of killing cold, but it managed to escape the clutches of two nearby packs of coyotes that have set up shop here in recent years, perhaps in response to the burgeoning cat population.

Without any cinder-block housing colonies, and zero supplemental friskies, these cats manged to survive a winter so deadly it killed *crows.*

In the comparibly mild environment of Long Island, there simply can be no justification for feeding and housing an obviously resilient and independent predator.
Well intended thought perhaps, but at close to 600mph and at 38,000 feet mental illness has a different degree of significance than it might, yes, even in a hospital operating room.
An autopsy?  They hit a mountain at 500 miles per hour.

Perhaps you have never seen the anatomic results of a high velocity impact.  A jet flying at 500 knots into a mountainside is very unlikely to leave body parts large enough to autopsy in the manner you suggest.

“He began to visit a series of doctors complaining first of psychiatric problems,and later of , difficulties with his vision.He visited the University hospital in February and in March for diagnostic tests.Doctors could determine no physiological cause for the vision difficulties,leading investigators to conclude that they may have been psychosomatic.”

Has an autopsy been performed? Why hasn’t anyone even raised the possibility that Mr .Lubitz may have had a brain tumor or another organic condition?

If Mr.Lubitz did not have a history of depression,,the vision problems he reported would probably have been taken more seriously,and for all we know,the 149 passengers and Mr.Lubitz would still be alive.

I know of several people whose "psychiatric problems" turned out to be brain tumors.One was hospitalized in a psych ward and given ECT. The other was put on anti-depressants.Their psychiatric symptoms did not abate.
While brain tumors may manifest as psychiatric symptoms, they will not respond to anti-depressants.

The reason a brain tumor came to mind is because visual difficulties followed the psychiatric diagnoses in these women who had brain tumors that were diagnosed as psychiatric.

The brain tumor killed one of these women,after it blinded her. She didn’t take anyone with her.Perhaps Mr. Lubitz would not have,if any of the many doctors he consulted had actually helped him.

Perhaps the problem is that none of those 15+ clowns deserves to be taken seriously.

Eventually the Republicans will pick a clown. Then we'll have a serious problem to discuss.

The authors of this article never bother to tell readers that Silkair is a Singaporean government-linked airline, let alone interview Singaporean aviation authorities about their response to the 1997 crash.  Why is this, one has to wonder?

Licensed clinical social workers and crisis workers (whose education and training aren't even addressed) are better trained than psychiatrists, who are physicians with completed residencies in psychiatry? I think not.

As a school supervisor I was REQUIRED BY LAW to investigate ANY ACCUSATION of physical abuse by a staff member (including teachers) and report it to the superintendent's office if there was any evidence or sign of abuse. By the same law I was required to report sexual abuse to the police for investigation by the sex crimes unit.

Many/most of the accusations were exaggerated or unfounded. PERSONAL PRIVACY does not matter in a school when it comes to the safety and protection of children.

Why should PERSONAL PRIVACY matter when a mass murderer is at the controls of a passenger airplane?

"Lubitz' visits to numerous doctors could have raised red flags if Germany didn't have all those privacy restrictions" and the physicians knew of his employment.

There is no legal requirement in the US or, probably in Germany, for a patient to disclose his or her employment to a medical practitioner. Given everything else we are assuming about Mr. Lubitz,we certainly are entitled to assume he declined to share details of his employment with his doctors, including those who wrote him excuses from work.

Murder-suicide is poorly understood even by forensic psychiatrists, so even the best screening methods will still be poor screening methods. That said, Lubitz' visits to numerous doctors could have raised red flags if Germany didn't have all those privacy restrictions.
No excuse for killing 149 other people.
Or he could have had depression with psychosis.

Journalism is supposed to be objective!  Part of the Society of Professional Journalist's code directs journalists to "Seek Truth and Report It."  By that measure, this column and other recent ones by NYT columnists falls short.
You are incorrect. The FAA allows certain antidepressants. They didn't in the past, but they do now.
Agree with two of your examples but not the third; scoliosis doesn't necessarily preclude one from ballet,  former NYCB principal ballerina Wendy Whelan has scoliosis.

Perhaps the difference is that passengers on ground transport have some chance to escape and/or survive.  A passenger trapped in a plane 38,000 ft. above ground has no chance of survival, if a pilot decides to crash the plane he is driving.  Huge difference.

You're being very delicate about not suggesting that this murder had a very German element to it -- that Germans wouldn't believe that a clean young German could do such a thing, or that the company had any responsibility for putting a homicidal maniac in charge of an airplane.

Clearly, this can and has happened in other countries, and the industry as a whole has been pigeheaded about the idea that its hero pilots could be killers, but Germany's continued delicatesse in this matter is disturbing.
Point well taken except for scoliosis: Wendy Whelan, the recently retired NYCB principal dancer, has scoliosis and she was at the top of her profession.

Most beautifully written and illustrated!  Almost poetic, and (for me) nostalgic.  In my younger years, I lived in Alaska, some of the time in territorial years.  Grayling, and trout were abundant.  We ate every fish we caught.  Later, we caught salmon, halibut, red snapper and harvested crab, clams and abalone.  What a treasure!  But we never wasted.  We canned, froze, pickled and smoked salmon.  It was the appreciation of what nature offered, the satisfaction in providing sustenance, and the joy of being part of the circle.
